answers.answer: Without seeing the scans and the biopsy I can not tell you what this represents. If you are concerned obtaining a second opinion with another spine surgeon is reasonable. Try to have the biopsy slides also reviewed by another pathologist. This will confirm the initial result. If this is determined to be benign, then following it up with a scan may be reasonable.However, the symptoms in his arms may not be related to the lesion. Perhaps also seeing a neurologist to confirm that no other disorder is occurring would also be reasonable. Good luck.

question: Good MorningMy 31 year old son has a spine lesion in the T3 vertebrae bone, with nuclear cell activity.He Has DDD , he had a L 5 spine fusion three years ago, he has diabetes type two.
